DIV1.P: AN EPISTLE FROM THE Princess SOBIESKI TO THE Chevalier DE ST. GEORGE.
By Mr. N. AMHURST, of St. John's College in Oxford.

Q.P: Quam legis à RAPTA Briseide Littera venit.

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for E. CURLL in Fleet-street, MDCCXIX.

DIV1.HEAD: AN EPISTLE FROM THE Princess SOBIESKI, &c.

LG.L: TO Thee, dear JAMES, my Lover and my Friend,
From Inspruck's Tow'rs these mourn∣ful Lines I send,
Where in a Cloister, by unjust Alarms,
The German Pow'rs with-hold me from thy Arms;
To Thee, Britannia's Native, exil'd KING,
I send in Writing what I fain would bring,
Long Health I send, and, void of winning Art,
The kindest Wishes of a Love-sick-Heart.
As to thy Arms my flying Steps I sped,
Wing'd with the Pleasures of thy promis'd Bed,
While my big Heart with eager Transports rose,
And swell'd, unconscious of approaching Woes,
Ye Gods! how shocking was the dire Decree,
That snatch'd Me from those Pleasures, and from Thee?
With Grief and Rage I heard the dreadful Tale,
My Limbs grew feeble and my Cheeks turn'd pale.
My trembling Heart forgot its wonted Pride,
And my Blood crept along, a frozen Tide.
No Joys to Me these lonely Walls afford,
Wrapt in the Fortunes of my absent Lord;
Let spleenful Prudes and antiquated Maids
Affect the Convent's solitary Shades,
Make Mid-night Zeal and Chastity their Care,
And starve the Sense with Abstinence and Pray'r;
Ill suits with me this dull, abstemious Life,
Who want to be a Mistress or a Wife;
How vain to Me, whose Breast with Passion beats,
These dark Recesses and obscure Retreats?
My burning Pulse no Vows can e'er restrain,
Useless is Penance, and Devotion vain,
Whilst to my God I lift my solemn Eyes,
To Thee my wand'ring Thought in Transport flies,
From Wish to Wish incessantly I rove,
And drop the Beads in Extasies of Love;
Heav'n in my Pray'rs claims but the meaner Part,
My Lips alone; my Lover has my Heart.
Thou, Thou alone employ'st my pensive Mind,
And in thy Love all other Joys I find.
As thro' the Horrors of the silent Dome
I meditate in Tears on Thee and Rome,
For Thee and Rome my Vows to Heav'n address,
And all the Passion of my Soul confess;
My Flame the Holy Sisterhood reprove,
And cant Religion whilst I burn with Love;
Ev'n now the promis'd Moments I employ,
And my Limbs tremble with the distant Joy.
But O! What Torments did thy Bosom bear,
When first my sad Afflictions reach'd thy Ear?
What Rage and Sorrow did thy Soul divide,
Despoil'd of thy unhappy, loving Bride?
How did'st Thou weeping curse the impious Hand,
That durst obey so lawless a Command?
How did'st Thou mourn this greatest killing Cross,
And think Three Kingdoms but a trifling Loss?
How did'st Thou wish for me alone to live,
And e'en great Brunswick in thy Rage forgive?
Unhappy Lover, and unhappy Man!
Whose early Suff'rings with thy Life began,
Whom angry Heav'n, surrounding Thee with Foes,
Seems to mark out a Monument of Woes!
Ill after Ill thy Royal Breast alarms,
In Love as unsuccessful as in Arms,
Eternal Wrath the cruel Fates ordain,
And to thy Wishes I am kind in Vain.
Still is the Victor in thy Fall employ'd?
How void of Conscience, and of Mercy void?
Will not the British Diadem suffice,
And does he still demand a dearer Prize? —
Swoln with Success, with bloody Laurels crown'd,
The World is for his Pride a narrow Bound;
Plum'd with imperial Greatness let him Reign
Lord of the Sea, and dictate Peace to Spain;
With France and Austria mighty Leagues design,
And with the potent Realms in Friendship joyn:
To his Decisions let all Nations yield,
Fam'd let him be in Council and the Field,
In Wealth, in Titles, and in Empire grow,
And of the Regal Honours strip thy Brow,
Great Alberoni's tott'ring Schemes controul,
And triumph in the Fulness of his Soul;
Not all his Grandeur shall thy Envy move
Let Him but grant Thee Sobieski's Love.
Possess'd of Me, to Him thou shalt resign
Thy bootless, lineal Claims, and Right Divine,
For Me Thou shalt renounce all future Schemes,
All Vain Aerial Hopes and flatt'ring Dreams,
Patient to Heav'n submit, and Heaven's Decree,
And find the Empire of the World in Me.
But how, ah! how, thus helpless and distrest,
How shall I meet Thee, take Thee to my Breast,
Hang round thy Neck, my furious Fires impart,
And whisper out the Fondness of my Heart?
Immur'd alas! I live from publick Sight,
And meditate with fruitless Arts my Flight,
Darkling in Mid-night Vigils I complain
That bounteous Heav'n has giv'n me Charms in vain:
Relentless Walls and Bolts obstruct my Way,
And Guards as senseless and as deaf as They,
Or to my James thro' Whirlwinds I would go,
Thro' burning Desarts and o'er Alps of Snow,
Pass spacious roaring Oceans undismay'd,
And think the mighty Dangers well repaid.
But thou at large, by more auspicious Fates
Securely roam'st thro' Fair Ausonia's States;
Ev'n thy poor Lot is less severe than mine,
Thee no strong Bars nor Prison-walls confine,
Thou art but simply wretched, Thou art free,
And Master of thy Will, compar'd to me:
Why therefore, arm'd with Justice on thy Side,
May'st Thou not rescue thy imprison'd Bride?
Quick at the Call accouter for the Fight,
And issue forth a bold advent'rous Knight,
Let Glory prompt Thee to the gen'rous Deed,
Grasp the tough Lance, and mount the fiery Steed,
Collect thy Vengeance, put forth all thy Soul,
And hasten from Ferrara to Tyrol:
The banish'd Duke shall his Assistance lend,
And Mackintosh and Forster shall attend;
With Blessings Clement shall thy Arm inspire,
And fearless Mar shall be thy trusty 'Squire;
Arm'd with such Friends the Sacred Dome invade
And from Perdition bear the Captive Maid.
Alas! What Rashness would my Love advise!
To what Excesses does my Passion rise!
y Thee shall Austrian Bulwarks be o'erthrown!
How Wild and how Romantick am I grown!
Rage, I Rave, on my pernicious Breath
istant Destruction hangs, and certain Death.
o, shun the fatal Counsel that I give,
orbear the Glorious, Rash Attempt, and live,
Imperial Wrath, O! Dare not to oppose,
Nor draw upon thy self such dreadful Foes;
As well on mighty George, that envy'd Name,
Again thou might'st renew thy baffled Claim,
In Arms once more provoke him to the Fight,
And from his Thunder steal thy private Flight;
Whose Cause all Europe against Thee defends,
And Emperours are proud to be his Friends,
Invaded Monarchs to his Aid resort,
And throng with their Ambassadours his Court;
Each Nation listens to the Laws He makes,
And in his great Alliances partakes,
While Craggs and Stanhope in his Cause engage,
And with their Counsels heal the warring Age.
Nor art Thou skill'd in Arms by Land or Sea,
And Fighting is an Art, unknown to Thee;
The martial Sword Thou know'st not how to wield,
And the loud Cannon scares Thee from the Field,
Bloodshed and Death thy trembling Heart possess;
(Ev'n all thy Friends the well-known Truth confess,)
Unfit, alass! Heroick Acts to dare,
To storm the Castle and relieve the Fair,
In bloody Justs to poize the beamy Launce,
And charm the Ladies in a new Romance.
No; thy proud Rival rather humbly greet,
And fall a lowly Suppliant at his Feet,
Strive with submissive Arts to gain his Ears,
With Pray'rs, Intreaties and persuasive Tears,
Thy bold Pretensions to his Crown deplore,
And promise never to disturb him more:
Say farther, that an helpless, dying Maid,
Implores his Pity, and conjures his Aid;
Say that a Princess, beautiful and young,
Who never yet offended, knows no wrong,
His Title never, nor his Right deny'd,
Begs by his Truth and Justice to be try'd,
Longs his unbounded Clemency to bless,
And his great Goodness with his Foes confess;
Say that to Him her Sufferings She commends,
Say on his Mercy that her Life depends,
Say all thou can'st; and for the Want of Art,
Let Tears express the Meaning of thy Heart:
At length perhaps his gen'rous Soul may melt,
Touch'd with a Passion which Himself has felt,
His Candour to the World he may approve,
And send forth Orders to release Thy Love.
Nor groundless is the Hope; for join'd to Thee,
Alas! what Dangers can He fear from Me!
I have no Armies in thy Cause to fight,
No Friends to question or dispute Thy Right,
To Crowns I neither dare nor wish to tour,
It is not in my Will, nor in my Pow'r.
Crowns are to me ridiculous and mean,
Nor would I, if I could, be call'd a Queen,
Ambition never yet disturb'd my Head,
T gen'rous Lover, not the King, I wed,
The golden Wreath and Scepter I despise,
Thou art alone to Me the richest Prize.
Were my great Sire alive, Immortal King!
With whose Exploits remotest Nations ring,
In vain Himself would in thy Cause engage,
And stem th' impetuous Torrent of the Age,
Tho' crown'd with Fame, and dreadful from afar,
(Great as he was) the Thunderbolt of War;
For still we must allow, what none denies,
That BRUNSWICK is as valiant and as wise;
In vain thy Friends his deep Designs oppose,
As fam'd in War, as dreadful to his Foes.
But He is dead, and I am left alone,
Weak, and unable to attempt a Throne;
To teaze Thy Foes indeed, officious Fame
Reports Me wealthy, magnifies My Name,
And boasts my Pow'r; but Fame, O gentle Youth!
Like other Maids, not always speaks the Truth:
'Tis a good Maxim, well-approv'd, and old,
That Female Dowries swell as oft as told;
Those fickle, wav'ring Stocks, in sooth to say,
Fall Cent. per Cent. upon the Wedding-Day.
No present Dangers from our Love arise,
No wealthy Treasures, and no strong Allies;
No potent Armies to disturb his Reign,
No Force by Land, nor Empire o'er the Main;
Yet studious our united Souls to part,
Still some new Plea the Conqueror may start,
His Care to future Ages may extend,
And into distant, dark Events descend:
Perhaps, to guard his Throne, He may desire
That with Thy Breath Thy Title may expire;
Resolv'd Thy Name for ever to deface,
And stop the Issue of the STUART Race:
Yet groundless too such Jealousies appear,
Begot in sickly Brains, the Dreams of Fear:
For should the Stars this greatest Boon afford,
And, Mistress of my Wish, I call Thee Lord:
Tho' Heav'n shou'd bless Us with a num'rous Line,
And Our Seed flourish as the branching Vine;
Tho' fruitful as thy UNCLEKing CHARLES II. Thou should'st prove,
Of glorious Fame, that Prodigy of Love!
In vain thy vengeful Heir, when Thou art Dead,
Would strive to pluck the Crown from Brunswick's Head;
In vain would strive, in his Ambition crost,
To gain the Kingdoms which his Father lost;
Compell'd, like him, to drop his baffled Claim,
And wear, of England's King, the barren Name:
For now quite stale the Passive Doctrine grows,
Scoff'd and derided by Thy learned Foes;
The Danger of the Church begins to cease,
And with each rising Sun thy Friends decrease;
No longer in a ruin'd Cause confide,
And one by one desert to Brunswick's Side.
But, if relentless to our common Grief,
And mutual Anguish, he denies Relief,
If, tho' no Dangers can from hence arise,
He still detains Me from Thy longing Eyes;
Death shall release Me from insulting Woe,
Death is My Friend, tho' Brunswick be My Foe:
Robb'd of My dearest Hopes, how vain is Life,
With all the Passions in my Breast at Strife?
'Tis mean to live, when Life becomes our Curse,
'Tis base, ignoble, Cowardise, and worse!
I will not be a Wretch still wreck'd with Care,
And linger out my Life in dull Despair;
Dying, my constant Passion will I prove
A mournful Instance of ill-fated Love;
I'll grasp the pointed Sword, or drench the Bowl,
And vindicate the Freedom of My Soul.
And Thou, dear Object of my bleeding Heart,
In My last Agonies shalt bear a Part:
With pitying Tears Thou shalt My Loss deplore,
When first it shall be told that I'm no more—
Should Heav'n for Thee a milder Fate ordain,
Still in Thy Thoughts let SOBIESKI reign;
Bless'd in th' Embraces of another Bride,
O! still remember that for Thee I dy'd;
Tho' wretched here, and robb'd of worldly Peace,
on with My Life shall My Misfortunes cease;
My Tale in distant Ages shall be told
e fav'rite, moving Theme of Young and Old:
n Eloisa's Name shall be forgot,
d Worlds hereafter mourn my harder Lot,

DIV1.HEAD: BOOKS lately Printed for E. CURLL.

LIST.ITEM: . THE LIVES and CHARACTERS of all the English Dra∣matick Poets. With an Account of their Writings; A∣orn'd with the Effigies of the most Eminent Authors. Curi∣ously engraven from Original Paintings by Mr. Vertue and Mr. Vander-Gucht. Price 6 s. the small, 15 s. the Royal Paper.
II. Mr. ADDISON's Poems on several Occasions. Collected into one Volume. With his Dissertation on the Roman Poets. Adorn'd with Cuts. Price 5 s.
III. Mr. ROWE's Poetical Works. Collected into one Vol. With his Effigies curiously engraven. Price 4 s.
IV. The Earl of HALIFAX's Poetical Works. With his Life, his Last Will and Testament, and a Character of his Writings. By Mr. Addison. Price 5 s.

V. Major PACK's Miscellanies, in Two Parts. 1. Consisting of Original Poems, and Translations from Ovid, Virgil, Catul∣lus, Tibullus, and Propertius. 2. Essays upon Study and Con∣versation, &c. The 2d Edition. Price 3 s. 6 d. the Small, 7 s. the Royal Paper.
VI. The Life of POMPONIUS ATTICUS. With Remarks. By Major PACK Price 1s. 6d. the small, 3s. the Royal Paper.
VII. The NOONING: a Poem. Translated from Ovid, at the Request of a young Lady at the last Ball. By Major Pack. Price 4 d.

VIII. The Court Gamester; or, full and easy Instructions for Playing the Games now in Vogue, after the best Method, as they are Play'd at Court, and in the Assemblees, viz. Ombre, Picquet, and the Royal Game of Chess. Wherein the Frauds in Play are detected, and the Laws of each Game annex'd, to
prevent Disputes. Written for the Use of the young Prince¦ses. By Richard Seymour, Esq Price 2 s. bound.
IX. The English Theatre: Consisting of the New Play acted at both Houses, in the Years 1716, 1717, and 1718. B his Majesty's Servants. In 3 Volumes. Price 13 s.

X. OVID in Masquerade; being a Burlesque Poem upon th xiiith Book of his Metamorphoses; containing the Celebrated Speeches of Ajax and Ulysses. Design'd for the Entertainment of those who had rather Laugh and be Merry, than be Mer∣ry and Wise. By Mr. Joseph Gay. Price 1 s.
XI. A Poem on the LAST-DAY. Adorn'd with Cuts▪ Price 1 s.

XII. The Force of Religion: Or Vanquish'd Love. A Poem in Two Books. (Illustrated in the History of the Lady JANE GRAY. Adorn'd with Cuts. Price 1 s. Both by Mr. YOUNG Fellow of All-Souls College, Oxon.
XIII. ESTHER Queen of Persia. A Poem in Two Books. By Mr. Henley of St. John's College, Camb. Price 1 s. 6 d.
XIV. Mr. PRIOR'S second Collection of Poems. Price 1 s.
XV. MUSAE BRITANNICAE è Poematis varij Argumenti ve hactenus ineditis, vel sparsim editis & rarissimis constantes. Pret. 2 s. 6 d.
XVI. BOILEAU'S Lutrin. In Six Cantos, Adorn'd with Cuts. Price 1 s. 6 d.
XVIII. POEMS. By Mr. JOHN PHILIPS, late Student of Christ-Church, Oxon. With his Life by Mr. Sewell, Price 1 s.
XIX. POEMS. By Mr. SEWELL. Price 2 s.
